defining Mathematics education: Presidential Yearbook selections, 1926–2012
Francis (Skip) Fennell and William R. Speer, eds., 2013. 410 pp., $59.95 cloth. ISBN 978-0-87353738-4. Stock no. 14551. National Council of Teachers of Mathematics; www.nctm.org.

This publication, the 75th NCTM Yearbook, is composed of article recommendations by nineteen former presidents of the National Council of Teachers of Mathematics. These presidents each recommended one article from past Yearbooks that was based on its “enduring quality and relevance” for mathematics education. This book’s wonderful collection  looks at “where we have been, where we are now, and where we are going” in mathematics education.

The purpose of this Yearbook is to celebrate and reflect on the history of the NCTM Yearbooks as a resource for mathematics education. Unfortunately, this is the last publication in the NCTM Yearbook series. It is being replaced with a new series titled Annual Perspectives in Mathematics Education.

Reading each of the chapters made  me appreciate the history of mathematics education. The first chapter, “On the Foundations of Mathematics” from 1926, was an interesting read. From it, I gained perspective, realizing that the discussion of reform mathematics rings true in present-day mathematics education. I also enjoyed the abstract introducing each chapter in which the editors gave some background information about the material and what the reader would find interesting. This is a nice touch that this reader appreciated. I especially enjoyed some of the chapters that provided some problem-solving activities.
NCTM presidents deliver an  annual presentation during each of the two years of their presidency, and several of the chapters in this book

are those presentations. Readers also need to realize that many of these articles are discussing mathematics education K-grade 12. This book is packed full of ideas for mathematics educators, consultants, and specialists, as well as professors of preservice teachers.

I work with preservice and in- service teachers, and this Yearbook is definitely useful for this audience. The first chapter is important in that it permits these audiences to compare and contrast mathematics education of the past with the present. That assignment allowed these teachers to gain perspective about how mathematics education has changed over the years. I highly recommend this book.
—Greg Gierhart
Murray State University
Murray, Kentucky developing essential  Understanding of statistics, grades 6–8

Gary D. Kader, Tim Jacobbe,  Patricia S. Wilson, and Rose Mary Zbiek, eds., 2013. Foreword by Henry Kepner. 112 pp., $36.95 paper. ISBN 978-0-87353-672-1. Stock no. 13800. National Council of Teachers of Mathematics; www.nctm.org.

With a clear alignment to Standardsbased practices, Developing Essential Understanding of  Statistics, Grades 6-8 provides eductors with a thorough as well as easy-to- understand examination of the major concepts in this domain. The authors provide a detailed journey through  the essential ideas of statistics by punctuating their book with dozens of illustrative visuals that highlight key points in the examples.

This text, perfect for new or experienced math educators, organizes the study of statistics for grades 6-8 into four main categories. Termed “Big Ideas,” each of these four is further articulated as a series of “Essential Understandings” written in studentfriendly language and thoughtfully explained. The interesting examples set in contemporary contexts would be appropriate for use with students in grades 6-8. With an enduring emphasis on engaging students in the problem-solving process, the authors purposefully frame each example around four main ideas in the process of generating and using statistics: formulating questions, gathering and analyzing data, and interpreting results.

In addition to the explanations of  key statistics concepts at this level, the authors also make clear connections to how these ideas fit into the K-grade 12 experiences of students while also explaining how these ideas mesh with the other mathematical content of grades 6-8. The explanations of both vertical and horizontal alignment are useful not only for teachers but also for students.
Highly relevant and decidedly  accessible, this text would serve as a solid, Standards-based resource for any middle school math educator.  —Anita Bright
Portland State University
Portland, Oregon

Math expressions: developing  student thinking and Problem solving through communication
Cathy Marks Krpan, 2012. 174 pp., $47 paper. ISBN 978-0-32-175615-2. Pearson Canada; www.pearsoncanada.ca.

Reading and writing in the math classroom? Giving heed to reading and writing in math lessons has always been part of NCTM’s Process Standard of Communication and is now emphasized in the Common Core’s Standards for Mathematical Practice. Cathy Marks Krpan’s Math Expressions: Developing Student Thinking and Problem Solving through Communication provides teachers with practical tools for creating a communication-rich mathematics learning environment.

Krpan’s book synthesizes research on and activities for cooperative learning, discourse, reading, and writing in the mathematics classroom. The  “teaching strategies” section of each chapter is filled with activities that provide information about cooperative structures for communication in math lessons. In addition, each chapter contains research summaries, facilitation tips, ways to support ELLs, and assessment suggestions.

The book’s photographs and classroom examples illustrate the activities in action. For instance, the author describes a variety of graphic organizers that assist math learners in communicating their ideas in writing. Photographs of student examples demonstrate these graphic organizers and their purposes, thus allowing the reader to envision how these tools could be useful in his or her own classroom. Blackline masters at the end of the book and a companion website provide premade resources, although most teachers will likely want to adapt and tailor these examples to their own classroom.

I recommend this book for teachers looking for new ideas and simple ways to enhance the mathematics communication and collaboration among their students. This book could also be particularly useful for those interested in capitalizing on the reading and writing inherent in every math lesson.
—Jessica F. Shumway
Utah State University
Logan, Utah
Math tools, grades 3-12
Harvey F. Silver, John R. Brunsting, Terry Walsh, and Edward J. Thomas, 2012. 272 pp., $38.95 paper.  Corwin Press; www.corwin.com.

Although differentiated instruction is not a novel idea, the integration of the Common Core State Standards for Mathematics has increased the call for resources for designing quality, differentiated learning opportunities. Silver, Brunsting, Walsh, and Thomas offer just such a resource; Math Tools,

Grades 3-12 is a broad, wellorganized collection of tools that teachers can use to design the best lessons and units to appeal to diverse learning styles and needs. This book could be used individually by classroom teachers or as a resource for professional learning teams. Although the book is well organized, it may be overwhelming for teachers who are new to differentiating instruction; in this case, it would serve best in a collaborative environment.

The authors have organized the book into sections by the four different mathematical styles; the tool matrixes in each section made it easy to design a lesson or unit using the best tools for the unique learners in each group or class. I also found the descriptions and samples of student work to be helpful; however, these samples should not all be considered exemplars. The companion website, which offers ready-to-use copies of each of the tools, is most helpful.

I have enjoyed exploring and using this resource; it has helped me grow as a math teacher and as a leader. I would recommend this book to anyone looking for useful ideas to improve their instruction and student learning.
—Dawn Campbell
Orchard Hill Elementary School
South Windsor, Connecticut
Rti and Mathematics:  Practical tools for teachers  in K-8 classrooms
Regina “Gina” Harwood Gresham and Mary E. Little, 2013. 240 pp., $31.99 paper. ISBN 978-0-13- 300701-5. Pearson Education;  www.allynbaconmerrill.com.

RTI and Mathematics is another book for teachers and administrators to add  to their professional library. Although I am having mixed emotions about this textbook, I think it is a much-needed resource for all K-grade 8 professionals, especially math coaches and administrators. This book would be a great resource for a professional learning community to use when devising and implementing a plan on how to respond to intervention.

RtI, or Response to Intervention, is one of those buzz words that is currently circulating throughout classrooms. One thing that this textbook made clear is what RtI is and what RtI is not. “RTI is not a pre-referral model or a separate stand-alone initiative. We do not want to wait and see if  students fail, but rather offer opportunities for them to respond to lessons that differentiate and scaffold to build on the skills necessary to develop the knowledge base, competencies, and skills in mathematics” (p. 3). This one statement alerted me that I was in for a real educational treat.

In general, I recommend that this  textbook be read in either a book study or used in a professional learning community. In those ways, educators could use the tools to develop strategies and activities for their grade level and perspective needs. Despite the book’s having several tools, I wish it had more examples related to math content. For this reason, I have mixed emotions about it. For example, there is a section on tiered learning. I would have loved to have seen a more detailed sample of tiered instruction. I realize that this textbook is a means of  developing an RtI plan for mathematics, which may account for its generality. However, RtI might be new to some; more examples to accompany the forms would have been useful.
—Tomika R. Altman-Lewis
Burton Magnet Elementary School
Durham, North Carolina solving for Why: Understanding, assessing, and teaching students Who struggle with Math
John Tapper, 2012. 256 pp., $35.95 paper. ISBN 978-1-935099-33-8. Math Solutions; www.math solutions.com.

John Tapper’s book is a useful resource for anyone whose professional responsibility includes mathematics instruction. Addressed in his book is the role of administrators, instructional coaches, resource teachers, special education

Solving for

Why is user-friendly. It is divided into three sections: understanding why students struggle, three strategies to identify the reason students struggle, and how to support struggling students. Throughout the book, sidebars titled “Ease the Struggle” clarify information, such as the RtI model, or summarize key information that readers would likely want to locate quickly.
Throughout Solving for Why,

Tapper shares his personal experiences as an instructional leader working with struggling math students. Many suggestions, including the lessons learned  by Tapper and his colleagues, are designed to assist teachers in avoiding the same pitfalls that they encountered. As a classroom teacher, I often found myself pausing as I read the book to jot down notes so that I could use the strategies with my students. In other words, I could immediately see the usefulness of the protocols. In fact, I was able to easily create and administer the CRA (constructed response assessment) the first day that I returned to school after finishing the book.
Solving for Why is an easy-to-read guide that will provide effective and targeted intervention for math students, especially as RtI becomes the structure for identifying and supporting learners.
—Beth Cooke
Rolling Valley Elementary School
Springfield, Virginia
